bioghist.p: Ichthyology has been a part of research at the Academy of Natural Sciences since its beginnings, but its importance has increased dramatically since 1898 when it acquired the entire personal collection of the famous 19th century naturalist Edward Drinker Cope and Henry Weed Fowler became its first full-time curator. The collection has continued to grow in size, scope, and importance; the department is now rated as one of the top five ichthyology centers in North America. It currently houses 1.2 million cataloged specimens representing an estimated 11,000 species and 2,797 primary types. The collection is taxonomically diverse, but it's especially strong among eels, characiforms and catfish. Its geographic scope is world-wide, but its strengths include freshwater species of North and South America and marine species of the Bahamas, Western Atlantic and Indian Oceans. Continued growth results from recent expeditions to the Bahamas, South America and Asia.

scopecontent.p: This collection documents the activities of the Ichthyology Department of the Academy of Natural Sciences from 1954 to 1991. Materials include annual reports (1956-1981), a list of the department's employees, histories of the department and its collections; records related to funding; curatorial grant proposals and reports; records of expeditions and special projects; and correspondence of several members of the department's staff, including Eugenia Bohlke, James Bohlke, Phillip Heemstra, William F. Smith-Vaniz, and James C. Tyler. The correspondence relates to grants for expeditions, research projects, and preparation of specimen catalogs. The collection also includes commentary and field notes by Harry Pederson on his underwater films (1958-1976); a handwritten journal of a 1977 Venezuela (Rio Caura) expedition kept by William G. Saul, collection manager; and printouts of database records of specimens collected on expeditions, 1951-1991.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
